title: Wilts and Berks Canal Walking Route

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / Wilts and Berks canal, south of Swindon
images.caption: Wilts and Berks canal, south of Swindon

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / Route of Wilts and Berks canal, Swindon
images.caption: Route of Wilts and Berks canal, Swindon. The canal fell into disuse about 100 years ago. This view is along the line of the route facing north-east. Ahead is Milton Road bridge hidden by the tree. The silver building is the David Murray John tower. The car at the right is in the back yard of a house in Curtis Street.

images.title: Nigel Cox / Swindon: Former Wilts and Berks Canal
images.caption: Viewed from the top of the old railway bridge, the surface of the canal is entirely covered in an undisturbed fine weed. This reach of the canal was restored in the late 1990s having been abandoned in 1914.

images.title: Nigel Cox / Swindon: Disused canal and dismantled railway
images.caption: Disused canal and dismantled railway. The bridge was built about 1880 for the Midland and South Western Junction Railway. The railway is now closed and the bridge carries a cycle route.

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / Wilts & Berks canal near St Helen's View, Swindon
images.caption: Near St Helen's View, Swindon The canal runs past an attractive residential area on the western edge of Old Town. Some of the highly priced properties there enjoy good views from their elevated position above the canal.

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / Wilts and Berks canal and St Helen's View, Mill Lane, Swindon
images.caption: St Helen's View, Mill Lane, Swindon. The disused canal is under restoration but isn't navigable, at least this far along it. The bridge in the distance has been restored and carries a bridleway over the canal.

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / The River Ray near the Wilts and Berks canal, Swindon
images.caption: The River Ray near the Wilts and Berks canal, Swindon. The River Ray is one of two small rivers that drain into the Thames in the Cricklade area. The housing area to the left is fairly recent.

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / Wilts and Berks canal, near Wroughton, Swindon
images.caption: Near Wroughton. The canal carries on from here towards Wootton Bassett where the section with water in it ends.

description: Enjoy a stroll along this pleasant section of the Wilts and Berks Canal in Swindon. The walk starts in the town centre and follows the canal towpath to West Leaze Farm. On the way you'll pass the River Ray and the Rushey Platt Nature Reserve where you can look out for the water-vole. The canal runs on to Melksham via Wootton Bassett and Chippenham. Near Chippenham there is a section of the National Cycle Network running from Pewsham to Lacock Abbey. You can see this on the video below. To extend your walk you could try our Swindon Canal Circular Walk and visit the nearby Lawns Park and Queen's Park.
